content: I am a PhD candidate in the Department of Sociology at Cornell University. My research focuses on social hierarchies, how individuals perceive their legitimacy, and how they affect social cohesion. I am also broadly interested in the use of computational methods (e.g. online experiments, machine learning, and natural language processing) to study interesting sociological questions.

title: Mario D. Molina

title: Curriculum Vitae

content:
Published Work  Molina, Mario D., Mauricio Bucca, & Michael W. Macy (2019), “It is not just how the game is played, it is whether you win or lose”. Science Advances, vol. 5, no. 7, eaau1156. (click here).  Press Coverage: The New York Times, The Washington Post, U.S. News, The Japan Times, The Telegraph, New Scientist, ZME Science, Cornell Chronicle, among others.
 Molina, Mario & Filiz Garip (2019), “Machine learning for sociology”, Annual Review of Sociology, vol. 45. (click here)
  Work in Progress  Molina, Mario D., “Resting on your laurels? Status dynamics and individual effort in a large online community”.
 Molina, Mario D., Lisha Liu, Hakan Holm, & Victor Nee, “Social norms and spillovers into cooperation with strangers”.
 Garip, Filiz & Mario D. Molina, “Predictive machine learning models for exploring environment and migration linkages in historical Mexico-US. flows”.
 Drouhot, Lucas, Mario D. Molina, & Filiz Garip, “Identity and relational structure among immigrant adolescents in Western Europe”.
 Asad, Asad, Neil Jr. Lewis, & Mario D. Molina, “Profiles of psychological distress among noncitizens in the United States, 2011-2018”.
 Molina, Mario D. & Filiz Garip, “Network amplification”.
